IMAGE-THUMBNAIL APCATA 10982 S0926-860X(07)00247-5 10.1016/j.apcata.2007.04.018 Fig. 1 Potential–current curve for methanol oxidation reaction obtained with the present PtRu/C catalyst samples and a commercial PtRu catalyst (TEC61E54). Fig. 2 TEM micrographs of the present PtRu/C catalyst samples: (a) Sample A, (b) Sample B, (c) Sample C, (d) Sample D, (e) Sample E and (f) a commercial PtRu catalyst (TEC61E54). Fig. 3 XRD patterns of the present PtRu/C catalyst samples and reference peak positions of metallic Pt and Ru. Fig. 4 Pt LIII-edge XANES spectra of the present PtRu/C catalyst samples and reference materials, Pt0 metal, K2Pt2+Cl4 and Pt4+O2. Fig. 5 Ru K-edge XANES spectra of the present PtRu/C catalyst samples and reference materials, Ru0 metal, Ru3+Cl3 and Ru4+O2. Fig. 6 Radial distribution function of Sample A obtained at the Pt LIII-edge. The dashed line stands for a Hanning window function as a Fourier filter. Fig. 7 Fourier back-transformed EXAFS oscillation of Sample A obtained at the Pt LIII-edge and the fit result with the optimum parameters. Fig. 8 Fourier back-transformed EXAFS oscillation of Sample A obtained at the Ru K-edge and the fit result with the optimum parameters. Fig. 9 Schematic illustration of some PtRu nanoparticle models: (a) “random-alloy” structure, (b) “monolithic” particles, (c) “agglomerate” of clusters and (d) “core–shell” structure with a Pt-rich core and Ru-rich shell. Fig. 10 Schematic illustration of three cases of Pt-core/Ru-shell structured particles in which all Ru atoms are on the surface and cover a half of the surface: (a) one hemisphere is covered (b) these hemispheres are divided into four parts in total and two of them are covered, (c) these parts are divided again to obtain eight parts in total. Fig. 11 Correlation between methanol oxidation current at 0.4V and pairing factor, P Ru, calculated from results of Ru K-edge EXAFS analyses. Table 2 Optimized parameters obtained by the present Pt LIII-edge EXAFS analyses Sample ID Pt coordination Ru coordination σ 2 (nm2) ΔE 0 (eV) R-factor R Pt–Pt (nm) N Pt–Pt R Pt–Ru (nm) N Pt–Ru Sample A 0.274±0.002 4.3±0.5 0.273±0.003 1.7±0.2 5.0×10−5 6.6 0.008 Sample B 0.272±0.002 1.9±0.4 0.272±0.003 1.2±0.3 4.4×10−5 7.2 0.011 Sample C 0.273±0.002 2.0±0.5 0.273±0.004 0.9±0.3 5.8×10−5 7.9 0.017 Sample D 0.273±0.001 2.6±0.7 0.273±0.004 0.7±0.2 5.3×10−5 7.1 0.026 Sample E 0.273±0.002 2.8±0.6 0.273±0.003 0.9±0.2 5.3×10−5 6.8 0.025 Table 3 Optimized parameters obtained by the present Ru K-edge EXAFS analyses Sample ID Pt coordination Ru coordination σ 2 (nm2) ΔE 0 (eV) R-factor R Ru–Pt (nm) N Ru–Pt R Ru–Ru (nm) N Ru–Ru Sample A 0.273±0.003 1.9±0.6 0.268±0.001 6.7±0.7 6.7×10−5 −6.3 0.012 Sample B 0.271±0.003 2.1±0.4 0.268±0.002 2.9±0.4 6.9×10−5 −5.7 0.022 Sample C 0.273±0.003 1.7±0.6 0.268±0.003 1.5±0.4 7.7×10−5 −1.8 0.051 Sample D 0.273±0.003 1.8±0.5 0.268±0.003 1.0±0.3 7.7×10−5 −1.1 0.047 Sample E 0.273±0.002 2.2±0.6 0.267±0.003 1.0±0.4 7.3×10−5 −5.0 0.046 Methanol oxidation catalysis and substructure of PtRu bimetallic nanoparticles Hiroaki Nitani a ⁎ Takashi Nakagawa a Hideo Daimon b Yukiko Kurobe b Takahiro Ono a Yusuke Honda a Akiko Koizumi a Satoshi Seino a Takao A. Yamamoto a a Graduate School of Engineering, Osaka University, 2-1 Yamada-oka, Suita, Osaka 565-0871, Japan b Development & Technology Division, Hitachi Maxell Ltd., 6-20-1 Kinunodai, Tsukubamirai, Ibaraki 300-2496, Japan ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +81 6 6879 7886; fax: +81 6 6879 7886. Graphical abstract PtRu nanoparticles catalyst supported on carbon was synthesized and analyzed. The results indicated a clear correlation between the catalytic activity and Pt–Ru atomic pair frequency occurring on the particle surface, which support the “bi-functional mechanism”. Catalytic material of PtRu nanoparticles supported on carbon (PtRu/C) for direct methanol fuel cells was synthesized by a polyol reduction method. Addition of phosphorus was effective for downsizing PtRu particles and improving their catalytic activity. The activity obtained was six times of that of a commercial catalysis. The samples were analyzed by techniques of X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS) at Pt LIII-edge and Ru K-edge, transmission electron microscope (TEM), X-ray diffraction (XRD) and X-ray fluorescence (XRF). These results indicated a core–shell structure consisting of a Pt-rich core and Ru-rich shell. By examining coordination numbers determined by XAFS analysis, we found a clear correlation between the catalytic activity and the Pt–Ru atomic pair frequency occurring on the particle surface, which supports the “bi-functional mechanism”. Keywords PtRu bimetallic catalyst DMFC Bi-functional mechanism EXAFS Core–shell structure 1 Introduction Fuel cells have been attracting much attention as a next-generation power source for various applications [1–4]. Direct methanol fuel cells (DMFC) are one of the most promising power sources for movable and portable devices and electric vehicles. The DMFC uses methanol as its fuel, while other many types of fuel cell use hydrogen gas [5]. DMFC has a volumetric energy density about 10 times larger than the lithium ion batteries. However, the effective cell voltage of the DMFC is significantly lower compared with thermodynamic voltage because of a considerable overpotential occurring in methanol oxidation reactions at its anode. Platinum is intrinsically an excellent catalyst for methanol oxidation and is usually used in anodes in DMFC. Pt catalysts are, however, easily poisoned by CO formed on methanol oxidation. To overcome this problem, scientists have been looking for new Pt-based alloys with high tolerance for this CO poisoning [6,7]. PtRu alloy was found as a catalyst with a high CO tolerance [8–10], and its improvement was described as a “bi-functional mechanism” by Watanabe et al. [11]. Generally, downsizing of catalysis particles leads to a higher specific surface then to reductions in weight and cost of fuel cells [12,13], but no report was found regarding application of this mechanism to nanoparticles of PtRu alloy. For developing much more advanced catalytic material, it is necessary to check whether the “bi-functional mechanism” would be valid for the nanoparticles system. In this work, we synthesized PtRu alloy nanoparticles loaded on a porous carbon support by a polyol process technique. Phosphorus was added in the process to reduce particle size further [14–16]. The catalytic activity was measured by linear sweep voltammetry (LSV). Atomic substructure in the synthesized PtRu nanoparticles was examined by the X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS) measurements and some other complementary techniques: X-ray diffraction measurements (XRD), transmission electron microscope observations (TEM) and X-ray fluorescence spectroscopy (XRF) analyses. Correlations between these data sets regarding catalysis and structure were studied. The present result will provide a new insight into the atomic substructure of the catalysis and will contribute to development of more advanced fuel cells. 2 Experimental 2.1 Sample preparation Five samples (Samples A–E) of PtRu nanoparticles supported on carbon (PtRu/C) catalysts were synthesized by a polyol reduction method with various compositions of initially loaded materials, as tabulated in Table 1 . Only Sample A was synthesized without phosphorus, but the other four included it. Sample B was synthesized with less phosphorus than Samples C–E. Samples D and E were synthesized with less Ru than the others. The details of the synthesis procedure have been reported in references [17–21], so that it is only explained briefly here. Ethylene glycol was employed as a reductant and as a solvent as well. Platinum (II) bis-acetylacetonate (Pt(acac)2), Ruthenium (III) tri-acetylacetonate (Ru(acac)3) and carbon support were added into the ethylene glycol bath. A commercial nano-sized carbon black powder (VULCAN XC72R, Cabot Corp.), with a specific surface area of 254m2/g, was used as carbon support. The amount of carbon support was twice that of the noble metal in weight. An appropriate amount of sodium hypophosphite (NaPH2O2) was put into the solution as phosphorus source. To adjust the pH of the solution, we dropped sulfuric acid ill its pH became 3.0. Then the solution was refluxed at 473K for 4 or 1.5h with mechanical stirring under a nitrogen atmosphere to reduce Pt and Ru ions and make them become supported on carbon. Only Sample E was refluxed for 1.5h; the others for 4h. After ethylene glycol was evaporated, PtRu/C catalyst was obtained by washing successively with ion-exchanged water and ethanol, and drying under a vacuum with a liquid nitrogen trap. 2.2 Characterization of PtRu/C catalyst The catalytic activity of the sample was evaluated by the LSV technique. Measurements with 30mg PtRu/C catalyst sample were performed in an aqueous solution of 112.5ml containing 1.0mol/l sulfuric acid and 15vol.% of methanol at 298K in nitrogen atmosphere. An Ag/AgCl electrode was used as reference electrode and Au wires of 1-mm diameter were used as working and counter electrodes. Potential–current curves were obtained with an electrochemical analyzer (ALS Instruments, Model 701A) by varying the potential from 0 to 0.4V at a sweep rate of 10mV/s. For comparison, we also performed LSV measurements with a commercial PtRu/C catalyst (TEC61E54, Tanaka Kikinzoku Kogyo). Shapes and sizes of particles in the PtRu/C catalysts were observed by TEM (Hitachi HF-2200). Elemental analyse of the sample were performed by XRF (JEOL JSX-3220ZS). Crystallographic structure of the sample was analyzed by powder XRD (Rigaku RINT-1500 diffractometer) at room temperature with CuKα radiation with a wavelength of 1.54Å. The present XAFS measurements were performed at Pt LIII-edge (11549eV) and Ru K-edge (22120eV). The Pt LIII-edge X-ray absorption spectra were obtained at the BL-7C beam line of KEK Photon factory (high energy accelerator research organization, Tsukuba, Japan). The X-ray beam was focused by using an sagittal focusing Si (111) double crystal monochromator. Unwanted higher harmonic waves were eliminated by detuning the monochromator as the primary X-ray intensity became 60% of that before the detuning. For energy calibration, the first inflection point of the Au LIII-edge obtained from an Au thin foil was set to 11919eV. The Ru K-edge measurements were performed at the BL-19B2 beam line of the SPring-8 (Japan Synchrotron Radiation Research Institute, Sayo-cho, Japan). Si (111) crystals were used to monochromate the X-rays. To focus the X-rays and eliminate higher harmonic waves, we used an Rh mirror. The X-ray energy was calibrated by setting the first inflection point obtained from Ru powder to 22120eV. All the measurements were performed in air at room temperature with the transmission mode. The PtRu/C catalyst samples were mixed with an appropriate dose of boron nitride powder and shaped into 7-mm diameter pellets. Then the pellet was put into the X-ray path. The intensities of incident and transmitted X-rays were measured with ion chambers filled with N2(85%)+Ar(15%) mixed gas and Ar(100%) gas for the Pt LIII-edge measurements, and filled with N2(50%)+Ar(50%) and Ar(75%)+Kr(25%) for the Ru K-edge measurements, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic activity of PtRu/C catalyst Fig. 1 shows the potential–current curves obtained with the present samples, which reflect anode polarization involved in methanol oxidation. The catalytic activities of our five PtRu/C catalysts were higher than that of the commercial one, TEC61E54, and they are in the order of Samples A–E over the whole potential range. We noticed that the catalytic activity increases with increasing phosphorus addition to the source materials. Sample E has the highest activity, six times higher than that of the commercial material. 3.2 TEM, XRD, XRF and XAFS analyses Fig. 2 (a)–(f) are TEM micrographs of the synthesized PtRu/C catalysts Samples A–E and the commercial TEC61E54, respectively. The larger and gray particles are carbon support, and the smaller and black particle is noble metal nanoparticle. The metal nanoparticles are well dispersed on the surface of the carbon support. In Sample A, synthesized without phosphorus, PtRu nanoparticles involve a relatively wide particle size distribution in the range of 2–10nm, while the other four samples have average particle sizes of 2nm with far narrower size distributions. This size reduction caused by phosphorus addition has been already observed and understood to mean that a significant interatomic interaction of phosphorus with metal atoms may break metallic bonds to inhibit particle growth [14–16]. This downsizing must lead to increases in specific surface areas of the PtRu nanoparticles and to the enhancement of the catalytic activity. Indeed, Samples B–E with smaller particle sizes indicated higher catalytic activities than Sample A. Note that the only difference in synthesis condition between Sample A and Sample B is phosphorus addition and that their metallic compositions in the resultant samples were the same as shown in Table 1. However, Sample C showed a higher activity than Sample B, although there is no difference in their particle sizes. In addition, Sample E with the highest activity of the four samples involves almost same particle size as those of Sample B–D. These facts imply that there must be another factor besides the particle size that enhances the catalytic activity of Samples B–E. XRD patterns of the samples are shown in Fig. 3 , in which reference peak positions of the FCC-structured Pt metal (JCPDS #4-0802) and the HCP-structured Ru metal (JCPDS #6-0663) are also indicated. The diffraction peaks of Sample A were significantly shaper than those of the other four, which is in accordance with its largest particle size as observed by TEM. Regardless of the peak width, all the patterns showed diffraction peaks due to metallic Pt and not due to Ru. In addition, no significant peak shift from the positions corresponding to pure Pt was seen, although the present XRF measurements clearly indicated existence of Ru as listed in Table 1. These facts indicate that Pt exists as metallic particles, and that Ru may exist as too small clusters or too thin layers to give significant diffraction peaks. A small but significant amount of phosphorus (2.5–6.5 atomic percent) was detected in the resultant samples by XRF analysis. But according to the XRD and XAFS results described later, phosphorus seems not to bond with Pt. To summarize the present TEM, XRD and XRF analyses. Pt and Ru exist in the particles. Pt exists as metallic phase, but the chemical form of Ru is unclear at this stage. Figs. 4 and 5 are Pt LIII-edge and Ru K-edge X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) spectra of the synthesized PtRu/C, respectively, together with those of reference materials, Pt0 metal, K2Pt2+Cl4, Pt4+O2, Ru0 metal, Ru3+Cl3 and Ru4+O2. Since the features reflect the electronic excitations from inner orbital to the unoccupied continuum levels, we can estimate the information about atomic valence by comparing them. The peak positions of the samples’ Pt LIII-edge spectra well agree with that of the metal reference. On the other hand, Ru K-edge spectra of the present samples, especially Samples B–E, disagree with that of the metal reference but agree with that of the oxide reference. This means that the valence of Ru is higher than that of Pt in all the samples, so Ru may exist relatively on the particle surface and may bond with light elements, possibly with oxygen or phosphorus. The extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) oscillation was extracted by subtracting a background from experimentally obtained raw X-ray absorption spectrum. Then the spectrum was Fourier transformed into the radial distribution function (RDF). RDF of Sample A at Pt LIII-edge is depicted in Fig. 6 . Considering bond-lengths, the first peak reflects Pt–O and/or Pt–P bond, the second and the third peaks reflect both Pt–Ru and Pt–Pt bonds, respectively. To examine the structural analysis of the substructure of the PtRu nanoparticles, the second and the third peeks were exclusively Fourier back-transformed. Then Fourier back-transformed EXAFS oscillation χ(k) was submitted to a curve fitting procedure with the theoretical EXAFS function χth(k) [22]: (1) χ th ( k ) = ∑ j N j k R j 2 F j ( k ) exp ( − 2 σ 2 k 2 ) exp − 2 R λ j ( k ) sin ( 2 k R j + ϕ j ( k ) ) where R is the interatomic distance between X-ray absorbing atom and coordination atoms, N is the number of coordination atoms around an X-ray absorbing atom, σ 2 is Debye–Waller factor indicating degree of disorder, F(k) is backscattering amplitude of coordination atom, ϕ(k) is phase shift caused by a potential of atom, λ(k) is photoelectron's mean free path. The subscript j indicates the jth coordination shell; in the present fit, they correspond to Pt–Pt and Pt–Ru shells. The curve fit was performed with the “Artemis 0.7.015” code, and F(k), ϕ(k) and λ(k) were calculated by using “FEFF7” code assuming the single scattering path [23,24]. Optimized structural parameters in the present fit were R, N, σ 2, and ΔE 0. ΔE 0 is a correction to energy threshold E 0. Fig. 7 is the result of Pt LIII-edge EXAFS analysis of Sample A. The optimized structural parameters are summarized in Table 2 together with the R-factor which is an indicator for the precision of the fit [25]. These R-factors were small enough to assure the reliability of the present analyses. A subscript attached to R and N indicates the pair of absorbing atom and scattering atom. For instance, N Pt–Ru is number of Ru atoms coordinating around Pt at distance of R Pt-Ru. Ru K-edge EXAFS analysis was also performed by the same procedure with two paths of Ru–Ru and Ru–Pt bonds. Ru K-edge EXAFS analysis of Sample A is depicted in Fig. 8 . The structural parameters optimized from the Ru K-edge EXAFS analysis are summarized in Table 3 . In Tables 2 and 3, notice that there is no significant difference between interatomic distances R determined for Sample A, synthesized without phosphorus, and those of Samples B–E, synthesized with phosphorus. If phosphorus had existed in the nanoparticle as interstitial atoms, the interatomic distances should have changed. Therefore, phosphorus does not exist inside of nanoparticles, and it may exist outside of the PtRu nanoparticle or as adsorbed on carbon. 3.3 Substructure of the PtRu nanoparticle Here we are discussing the particles’ substructure that may have influenced the catalytic activity shown in Fig. 1. The XANES analysis above indicated that Ru would exist on the particle surface. To explain this result, we build four possible structural models of the PtRu nanoparticle, which are depicted in Fig. 9 (a)–(d). In these models, more than half of the Ru atoms exist in surfaces of nanoparticles in order to be consistent with the results of the XANES analysis. The validity of each of these substructure models was examined as follows. Firstly, the PtRu nanoparticle has a possibility of forming a random alloy nanoparticle, if we consider a phase diagram [26]. This model is depicted in Fig. 9(a). If the present samples include random alloyed PtRu nanoparticles, the ratios of coordination number of Pt and Ru coordination, N Pt–Pt/N Pt–Ru and N Ru–Pt/N Ru–Ru, should be consistent with the ratio of atomic fraction, x Pt/x Ru. For example, results of these calculation are N Pt–Pt/N Pt–Ru =2.5, N Ru–Pt/N Ru–Ru =0.28 and x Pt/x Ru =1.5 in Sample A, and these three values disagreed with each other. This tendency appears in the other four samples. In addition, the peak position of PtRu alloy in XRD pattern should shift to higher angle direction from the peak position of FCC-structured Pt metal [27,28]. But this phenomenon was not observed our XRD measurements. These results denied the random alloyed model. Secondly, we assume that Pt and Ru did not form the composite nanoparticle and formed the monolithic particle as depicted in Fig. 9(b). In this model, the monolithic particle should not have a Pt–Ru bond, but some Pt–Ru bonds are observed in the present EXAFS analyses. If Pt and Ru exist as the monolithic nanoparticles with the same diameter, Ru could give diffraction peaks as well as Pt. However, the diffraction from monolithic Ru particle does not appear in the present XRD measurements. So, we could deny this model. Thirdly, we considered cluster-in-cluster model, in which Pt and Ru small clusters agglomerate to form nanoparticles as shown in Fig. 9(c). This case is also dismissed by the results of XRD measurements. Though the size of Pt small clusters would be insufficient to give diffraction peaks as well as Ru, the diffraction peaks due to Pt was observed. From the above three reasons, we concluded that Pt and Ru form the composite PtRu nanoparticle with heterogeneous existence of Pt and Ru. Here, remember that the present samples were synthesized by the polyol process, in which coexisting aqueous Pt and Ru ions were reduced together. Ease of reduction is generally governed by the reduction–oxidation (redox) potential. Since the redox potentials of Pt2+/Pt and Ru3+/Ru are respectively, 1.18 and 0.69V, reduction of Pt ion is easer and metallic Pt is reasonably expected to be formed ahead of Ru. Therefore, we can expect that Pt ions are first reduced to form metallic particles and then Ru and remaining Pt ions are reduced on it to make up a core–shell like structured PtRu nanoparticle with a Pt rich core and a Ru-rich shell. Formation of bimetallic nanoparticles with such core–shell like structure has been reported for several systems [29–32]. The schematic illustration of such nanoparticle is given in Fig. 9(d). 3.4 Correlation between catalytic activity and particle's substructure Watanabe et al. have put forward “bi-functional mechanism” in 1975 to explain the origin of the high catalytic activity of the Pt-Ru catalyst [11], according to which a lower CO poisoning in the methanol oxidation by the Pt-Ru catalyst is given as follows [33]. During methanol oxidation, Pt is poisoned by CO and becomes Pt–CO. This CO-poisoning causes decline of active Pt sites and a decrease in catalytic activity. On the other hand, Ru in catalyst is not directly involved in methanol oxidation, but it reacts with H2O to form Ru–OH. If Pt–CO exists next to Ru–OH, they react with each other. (2) Pt–CO+Ru–OH=Pt+Ru+CO2 +H+ +e− Thus, CO is removed from the Pt site, and the Pt sites retrieve the catalytic activity. That is to say, existence of Pt–Ru atomic pair is an important factor for high activity catalyst. Of course, these pairs must be on the surface of the catalyst material. The number of the Pt–Ru pairs depends on the arrangement of Pt and Ru atoms and is reflected on the coordination numbers determined by the present EXAFS measurements. These coordination numbers are influenced by nano-size effects and inhomogeneous distribution of Pt and Ru atoms in the particles [28,29]. Therefore, we tried to extract information on the inhomogeneity from them. Here, we propose “pairing factor, P Ru” defined as, (3) P Ru = N Ru – Pt ( N Ru – Pt + N Ru – Ru ) It has a meaning of the probability that a Ru atom bonds with a Pt atom. Of course, it is obtained as averaged over the whole material. However, if the nanoparticles have a core–shell substructure shown in Fig. 9(d), Ru-K edge EXAFS analyses should be sensitive for Pt–Ru pairs occurring on the particle's surface. We are checking this segregation by referring to the P Ru as follows. We performed a semi-quantitative simulation for Ru–Pt pairs assuming that all Ru atoms are on the surface and cover a half of the particle surface. The composition of the particle is Ru/Pt=21/79 which corresponds to those of the Samples D and E. We took three cases shown in Fig. 10 and calculated P Ru for them: (a) one hemisphere is covered but the other is not; P Ru =0.56, (b) these two hemispheres are divided into four parts in total and two of them are covered and the other two are not; P Ru =0.59, (c) these parts are divided again to obtain eight parts in total; P Ru =0.61. It was demonstrated that P Ru increases with increasing number of islands of Ru atoms on the surface. The increase in P Ru could be ascribed as follows: if Ru–Pt pairs occur along the boundaries of the islands, then N Ru–Pt increases, and if Ru–Ru pairs occur in the islands, then N Ru–Ru decreases. From this consideration of the “pairing factor, P Ru” and the “bi-functional mechanism”, we can expect that the core–shell structured nanoparticle with high P Ru value should have high catalytic activity. The P Ru of the present samples and methanol oxidation current at 0.4V are plotted in Fig. 11 . There is a clear correlation between PRu and catalytic activity as expected above. Therefore, P Ru for the particle in which most Ru atoms are on the surface would well reflect Ru–Pt pairs exposing to the surface. These facts and all the other experimental results in this work support the hypothesis of formation of nanoparticles with Pt-rich core and Ru-rich surface, and that Ru–Pt atomic pairs on the surface indeed enhance the catalysis of methanol oxidation reaction. In other words, we demonstrated that the “bi-functional mechanism” is valid for the nanoparticles. Thus, we demonstrated the validity of the “bi-functional mechanism” even for the nanoparticle system by investigating the arrangement of Pt and Ru atoms by the EXAFS analysis. This work has revealed that the atomic arrangement at the surface is important and is correlated with the catalytic performance. Although the present particle seems to have favorable arrangement only at a surface region, wholly random alloyed nanoparticles with a similar diameter would be better from an economic viewpoint and for saving platinum resources. Synthesis of such particles overcoming the redox potential gap between Pt and Ru would be worth a challenge. We may be able to optimize the synthesis process and to maximize the catalytic activity, if we monitor and adjust the pairing factor by performing the in situ EXAFS measurement. Problems still remain regarding the roles of phosphorus both during synthesis process and catalytic reactions. But they are beyond the scope of the present work. 4 Conclusion Catalysts of 2-nm bimetallic PtRu nanoparticles supported on carbon were successfully synthesized with a polyol reduction method with phosphorus addition. Their catalytic activities for methanol oxidation were far higher than the commercial one; the highest one was six times greater. Coordination numbers and inter-atomic distances around Pt and Ru were probed by the EXAFS analysis, from which the catalytic activity was found to be correlated clearly with a pairing factor: P Ru = N Ru–Pt/(N Ru–Pt + N Ru–Ru). A high pairing factor corresponds to a high frequency of occurrence of Pt–Ru atomic pairs, which leads to depolarizing of CO-poisoning according to the bi-functional mechanism. Results of other complementary characterization techniques, XANES, XRD, TEM and XRF, are consistent with this model. It was suggested that Ru–Pt random alloy nanoparticles would be better from an economic viewpoint and for saving platinum resources. Acknowledgments The X-ray absorption experiments were performed at the BL-19B station of SPring-8 with the approval of the Japan Synchrotron Radiation Research Institute (JASRI) (Proposal No. 2005A0904-RI-p) and at the BL-7C station of Photon Factory with the approval of the High Energy Accelerator Research Organization (KEK) (Proposal No. 2005G032). coredata.dc:description: Catalytic material of PtRu nanoparticles supported on carbon (PtRu/C) for direct methanol fuel cells was synthesized by a polyol reduction method. Addition of phosphorus was effective for downsizing PtRu particles and improving their catalytic activity. The activity obtained was six times of that of a commercial catalysis. The samples were analyzed by techniques of X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS) at Pt LIII-edge and Ru K-edge, transmission electron microscope (TEM), X-ray diffraction (XRD) and X-ray fluorescence (XRF). These results indicated a core–shell structure consisting of a Pt-rich core and Ru-rich shell. By examining coordination numbers determined by XAFS analysis, we found a clear correlation between the catalytic activity and the Pt–Ru atomic pair frequency occurring on the particle surface, which supports the “bi-functional mechanism”.
coredata.dc:title: Methanol oxidation catalysis and substructure of PtRu bimetallic nanoparticles
